text:
INTERVIEWER:
Can you tell us your name and

what course you teach?
BUCCIARELLI:

Larry Bucciarelli.
I am a professor in the School

of Engineering.
And the course I teach in civil

engineering is Solid Mechanics.
The number is 1.050.

INTERVIEWER:
Can you tell us how the

materials that you have made
available through Open

Courseware are actually used in
the context of the class?

BUCCIARELLI:
Well, on the site you will find

the textbook which is not
completed.

Probably never will be
completed.

Engineering Mechanics for
Structures.

And that is the textbook which
the students purchase for the

price of replication by our copy
shop, but the chapters are also

available on the Web as pdf
files.

INTERVIEWER:
OK.

And what do the students do
with the materials in class?

Do they read it as homework?
Do you have them do exercises

in class?
BUCCIARELLI:

I found that the textbook works
very well, for me anyway

because, of course,
I have written it.

And so, I don't lecture so much
anymore.

I ask the students and I inform
the students that they are to

read the textbook before class,
when the text are assignment.

And that way we can do more
interesting things in class

other than myself standing in
front of a chalkboard with my

back to the students replicating
what is in the text.

INTERVIEWER:
Can you describe a typical day

or a typical lecture class
meeting?

BUCCIARELLI:
Well, again,

I tend not to lecture.
I will give some lecture,

but generally I like to go into
class and, at some time in the

class, introduce what I call a
class exercise of something that

I produced.
Again, in pdf file.

Not on Open Courseware because
these change from year to year,

but it is on my Stellar site.
And there is a little exercise,

very much like a problem set in
the problem exercise in the

textbook.
And there is a lot of blank

space on the page.
And I give these to students.

I ask them to work together in
teams of two or three and work

out the exercise.
And after maybe ten,

fifteen minutes of that we will
go through the exercise.

I will ask the students for
their comments and critique.

And, of course,
during the exercise I am going

around through the classroom
trying to answer their questions

if they have some.
And then I will move into maybe

a lecture mode for the duration
of the class,

but the idea is to get the
students engaged.

INTERVIEWER:
Are the students using

computers in the class or are
they doing this on paper?

BUCCIARELLI:
They are doing this on paper.

This is a first course in
engineering, a required course

in civil engineering.
Most of the students are

sophomores.
For most of the students it is

their first course in
engineering, but we do get some

students from architecture who
are in their third and fourth

years.
So, as a first course in

engineering, the emphasis is on
the fundamentals.

Now, fundamentals in two
senses.

The fundamentals of the theory,
which come over from physics

and engineering mechanics.
The title of the book is

Engineering Mechanics for
Structures.

But fundamentals also in the
sense of what is engineering

work like?
How do engineers make use of

approximations,
estimations and certain models?

So all of this is not the kind
of online productive production

activity of using a computer,
say, for exploring options in a

design setting.
Though, I do emphasize a design

context for some of my exercises
in the course.

INTERVIEWER:
Can you say more about those

exercises or what kind of
homework that the students do?

BUCCIARELLI:
Again, there are several kinds.

I have mentioned the class
exercise.

There are also standard home
problems.

Perhaps not so standard if you
look at the exercises at the end

of the chapters,
but let's call those standard

back of the chapter exercises.
And they are standard in the

sense that generally they have
one answer.

But there is another kind of
exercise which I highlight and

which counts 40% of the grade in
the course, and these I call

design or open-ended exercises.
And the students tackle six of

these during the course of the
semester.

They are conceptual exercises.
They are exercises in which

there is no one solution.
Some are shown in the textbook.

For example,
a diving board for a world

market.
There is no one answer,

and so they must document their
arguments and justification for

their designs.
And that they do in a journal,

$1.50, $2.00 or something like
that.

And, of course,
that is a different kind of

exercise for faculty,
too.

And there, in several ways,
one, it is going to take longer

to evaluate the exercise.
Though, perhaps a teaching

assistant might help in that.
Two, and more important,

it is different in the attitude
or the perspective that the

faculty has to take on the
exercise.

It is no longer a case where
there is a single answer,

nor even perhaps a single
method.

So that means the faculty has
to become a listener and not

just a lecturer in class.
Generally, the way I handle

these design exercises is to go
in with a class exercise that is

related to the upcoming design
exercise.

Have the student work through
that.

After all, the purpose of this
is not to teach design.

That is not my intent.
My purpose is to teach the

fundamentals of engineering
mechanics, of structures,

but to do it in a way where the
students are engaged as they

were taking on an engineering
project or a design project.

So this means that,
again, there is no single

answer, no single method.
That it is important that

students participate in the
formulation of the problem and

setting out constraints in
talking about the kind of

resources they can make use.
And here I let them use the Web

if they like.
They can call home to find out

the size of the diving board in
their backyard,

if they have one.
As long as they report and

reference their sources.
I find that these design

exercises work very well.
And, if I can say,

this is the commercial part,
I guess, of the broadcast.

And the students recognize
that.

Let me just read some comments
from the evaluation,

if I can, which I just
received.

They say things like Professor
Bucciarelli makes this class

difficult and fun at the same
time.

Another.
I found the content very

difficult but also very
challenging.

I enjoyed it greatly and
understood the concept but have

difficulty completing exercises.
I really enjoyed the class

because it was taught in a way
that made the material

interesting to us.
The design exercises were

extremely hard and time
exhausting, but they were very

interesting to do and they are
the reason I learned the

material.
Now, that, in a way,

is the kind of response I
welcome.

And it has generally been the
case that students do take to

the design exercise,
even though they are difficult.

I recall one journal when I
myself was up very late in the

night evaluating the journals,
and here was this statement

after pages and pages.
The student had written it is

2:00 AM in the morning and I am
going around in circles.

And I wrote back great,
you have discovered that design

is an iterative process.
Now, I could go in and lecture

about design is an iterative
process.

The students wouldn't
understand a damn thing about

what I was saying,
but when they experience it

themselves that is when learning
happens.

INTERVIEWER:
So how else would you assess

them if you said that is 40% of
their grade?

Through problem sets,
quizzes?

BUCCIARELLI:
Yeah, sure.

As show in the syllabus which
is also posted,

you will see that I think it is
40% that is on the design

exercises, 30% on the quizzes,
two quizzes,

standard quizzes again,
and 30% on a final exam.

I do not grade the problem sets
they are evaluated.

There are weekly problems sets.
They are evaluated by the

teaching assistant.
And we tell students to come

and see us if we note that they
are having some problems there.

But, of course,
not all the students tackle the

problems.
After a while,

you know, the course becomes
hard enough in itself in all its

other ways.
And students set their

priorities and have to engage
the design exercises,

quizzes of course.
And that is one of the reasons

why I use these class exercises
as well because they,

in a sense, are like problem
sets.

INTERVIEWER:
Do you anticipate making any

changes to the class in the
future or are you happy with the

way it is going now?
BUCCIARELLI:

I am quite happy.
I am continually making changes

in the sense of updating the
textbook.

I might warn any user or reader
of the text that there are some

places where there are some
typos and things like that,

some are quite serious.
And those are usually obvious,

though.
I don't anticipate changing the

course to a great extent.
I should mention there is a

laboratory course that goes
along with it,

which is half the units of the
Solid Mechanics course,

so it is a problem of
integrating lab exercises,

lab experiments with the
content of the course.

And that has taken a while,
but that seems to work quite

well, too.
INTERVIEWER:

Is there anything you want to
say about the laboratory course?

BUCCIARELLI:
Well, again,

my attitude,
and my attitude there is not to

do cookbook laboratories.
That is the student goes down

and turns a few dials and
watches a few outputs,

but to try to gauge the
students with the setting up of

an experiment which is very
important.

And all kinds of things can go
wrong with that,

and I want them to experience
that.

I want them to have some sense
of what kind of instrumentation

is available.
And here we consciously use

some very crude forms of
instrumentation in the early

experiments like dial gauges and
even meter sticks.

And then later on we move to
things like LBDTs for measuring

displacement in strain gauges
for measuring,

again, strains.
So there is an emphasis on the

experience of setting up an
experiment.

There is emphasis upon
instrumentation and seeing how

that can also,
how powerful certain points of

instrumentation can be,
but also how open to,

not misuse, well,
misuse and things going wrong

happens there.
So, again, the idea is to have

the student experience the
context of engineering work as

much as, say,
the principles of the

fundamentals of the content or
the focus in terms of structures

and mechanics.
Of course, report writing is

also an element of the course.
INTERVIEWER:

Great.
Well, thank you very much for

sharing your materials with MIT
OpenCourseWare.

We appreciate it.
Are there any last thoughts you

have on your teaching of either
of these courses?

BUCCIARELLI:
Well, no.

That's enough.
INTERVIEWER:

Great.
Well, thanks for your time.

BUCCIARELLI:
OK.
